Award.AwardTitle: High-Resolution Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry for Chemically Imaging Cell Membrane Organization
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program (CMI) in the Division of Chemistry (CHE) and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB), Professor Mary Kraft and her group at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign are developing new approaches to quantitatively image the subcellular distribution of distinct lipid species. Differences in the relative abundances of cholesterol among the membranes of various organelles influence mammalian cell function and are correlated with disease. Yet, current analytical tools are inadequate for assessing the cholesterol abundance within subcellular compartments. Professor Kraft and her team plan to address this need by developing a high-resolution secondary ion mass spectrometry method for quantitatively imaging cholesterol and sphingolipids within specific cellular organelles with high spatial resolution. This work entails the development and optimization of labeling strategies for organelle detection, depth profiling conditions, and quantitative data analysis methods, as well as determination of sputtering rates on mammalian cells.

The proposed research will yield a chemically specific approach for imaging the relative abundances of cholesterol and other lipid species in specific organelles or near intracellular proteins of interest with less than 100-nm-lateral resolution. This chemical imaging tool will greatly facilitate identifying the mechanisms by which cholesterol regulates intracellular trafficking, and ultimately, cellular function. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students in secondary ion mass spectrometry, cell biology, metabolism, quantitative bioanalytical chemistry, experimental design and hypothesis testing. Results will be incorporated into a lecture and laboratory activity that will be presented at the Girls' Adventures in Mathematics, Engineering, and Science (GAMES) Bio- and Chemical Engineering Camp for 9th and 10th grade young women.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project focused on developing a new strategy to image the distributions of cholesterol and sphingolipids within distinct intracellular membranes with high-resolution secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS). Mammalian cells contain several organelles, which are membrane-bound compartments that perform different specialized functions. Differences in the relative abundances of cholesterol and distinct lipid species within each organelle influence cellular function. However, when we began this project, the analytical tools for assessing the abundance of cholesterol and specific lipid species within distinct organelles were inadequate.

We developed new tools that might be used to image the relative abundances of cholesterol and a distinct lipid species called a sphingolipid within organelles of interest with high-resolution SIMS. We focused on detecting these biomolecules within the late endosomes and Golgi apparatus because their abundances within these organelles affect a basic cellular function, intracellular transport.  To enable assessing the relative cholesterol and sphingolipid abundance within the Golgi apparatus and late endosomes with high-resolution SIMS, a distinct stable isotope or non-native element must be incorporated into each organelle so that it produces distinctive secondary ions that can be used for identification.  For this reason, we genetically engineered a cell line that stably expresses the Golgi apparatus-specific protein, β-1,4-galactosyltransferase (β4Gal-T1), and the late endosome-specific protein, Rab9A, fused to a SNAP-tag or HaloTag protein, respectively. SNAP-tag and HaloTag proteins are small enzymes that catalyze a selective reaction between themselves and their ligands. Then we synthesized a fluorinated, fluorophore-labeled HaloTag ligand and a deuterated, fluorophore-labeled ligand, that selectively react with the organelle-specific HaloTag and SNAP-tag fusion proteins to enable their detection with high-resolution SIMS. We also optimized metabolic labeling protocols for selectively incorporating different distinct stable isotopes into the cholesterol, sphingolipids, and all lipid species within the genetically engineered cells to allow imaging their intracellular distributions with high-resolution SIMS. Together, these new tools are an important step towards imaging the relative abundances of cholesterol and sphingolipids relative to all lipid species in specific organelles with approximately 100-nm-lateral resolution. This capability would greatly facilitate identifying the mechanisms by which cholesterol regulates intracellular trafficking, and ultimately, cellular function. The results of this project have been disseminated through publication in peer-reviewed scientific journals, lectures to graduate students and faculty at other universities, and presentations at national and international conferences. We also presented our findings to the 11 high school science teacher participants in a Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program, and to over 40 9th - 11th grade young women at the Bio- and Chemical Engineering Summer Camp at the University of Illinois.

This NSF-funded project has provided research training and professional development for four female graduate students and three high school science teachers (a female chemistry teacher from a high school in Puerto Rico, and two science teachers from rural Illinois high schools with a significant fraction of Amish students). The graduate students acquired skills and training in chemical synthesis, product isolation and purification, molecular biology, cell culture, research code of conduct, experimental design, troubleshooting, scientific communication, imaging mass spectrometry and other analytical techniques.  They also acquired professional skills by preparing manuscripts, presenting their research results at conferences, leading high school students in laboratory activities, and mentoring high school teachers performing research in our laboratory. One of these graduate students is now an adjunct professor teaching chemistry at Sinclair Community College in Ohio.  The three high school science teachers received training in mammalian cell culture, chemical synthesis, purification, scientific methods, research code of conduct, and imaging mass spectrometry.  Each of these teachers produced a training module that teaches their high school students about mammalian cell biology, membrane biology, imaging mass spectrometry, scientific methods, and the research code of conduct. Lastly, over 60 9th - 11th grade young women who participated in a Bio- and Chemical Engineering Summer Camp at the University of Illinois participated in a laboratory activity related to the NSF-funded research project.
